content: Hundreds of Links in Over 38 Topics about Breast Cancer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p font font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong em span
content: You have to accept whatever comes,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong em span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong em span
content: Is that you meet it with courage—

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Once you have completed your treatments for breast cancer (including surgeries, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, etc.), you will naturally want to "get on with your life." Although each of us goes through the experience of being diagnosed with and treated for breast cancer differently, there may be some common issues that you will need to deal with either immediately or long after our treatment is over. Having an awareness of the possibilities puts you in a better position to know how to deal with them or where to turn for help if one arrives in your life.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: In this section, as in the previous one, we have chosen to address some of the more common "post-treatment" issues which many breast cancer survivors may be concerned with. Along with the resources we list at the end of this section, you should talk with your doctor about any health situation that gives you concern.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: I have breast cancer and had been taking hormone replacement therapy. Should I continue to take it?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Your doctor should advise you about whether to continue HRT (hormone replacement therapy) at the time you are diagnosed with breast cancer. Generally, hormone replacement therapy is not recommended for women who have been diagnosed with breast cancer.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Why would hormone therapy be given to women with breast cancer?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Researchers have found a way to use hormones as therapy against breast cancer. This is different than HRT (hormone replacement therapy), which is given to imcrease levels of hormones (such as estrogen and progesterone) that are decreased in the body due to menopause.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: One hormone therapy drug for breast cancer is Tamoxifen. By blocking estrogen, Tamoxifen can block the growth of cancer cells. If your tumor is estrogen receptor positive (called "ER positive") this may be a good treatment for your breast cancer. (Estrogen receptors are found in the nucleus or center of the tumor cell. The ER allows cells to use estrogen to grow). Tamoxifen can be used alone, with chemotherapy, or following chemotherapy. Tamoxifen is also being used to prevent breast cancers from developing. You may want to ask your doctor about this.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p strong a font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Lymphedema is the collection of lymph fluid that can occur in your arm and hand after your lymph nodes have been removed or damaged from your underarm area (axilla) during breast cancer surgery.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Lymph fluid is a colorless fluid containing the white blood cells that fight infection and disease. Lymph fluid travels through channels of the lymph system throughout your body much like blood travels through arteries and veins.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Lymph nodes are small, pea-sized organs located along the lymph channels. They are grouped in clusters. Their job is to trap foreign bodies such as bacteria or cancer cells to keep them from spreading throughout the body. The nodes are clustered in areas throughout your body such as underams (axilla), groin, neck, chest and abdomen. The ones in your chest and underarm are the ones that collect the lymph fluid from your breast. This is why they are often removed at the time of surgery.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: What causes the arm to swell after surgery?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Not every woman's arm swells after surgery. It swells because the number of pathways for the lymph to drain from the arm are reduced by the removal of or damage to the lymph tissue during surgery or radiation therapy. Fewer channels to drain the fluid can result in collection of fluid in the arm (or swelling). The extent of lymph tissue removed or damaged relates to how much swelling you may experience. Swelling may occur weeks, months or even years after treatment.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Are there any safety precautions I should be aware of?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Yes. Because the lymph channels and nodes have been removed (or decreased) on the side of your surgery, you must take extra caution to protect your hand and arm from injury, cuts, scrapes and insect bites. You may have less protection against infection in that arm. Some people wear a medical alert bracelet with this information on it. It is important to remind healthcare workers to avoid drawing blood and measuring your blood pressure on that arm. It is also recommended that you wear gloves while doing housework, gardening and other activities that may put your arm or hand at risk for injury. In addition, it is possible for lymphedema to occur years after you have finished your treatment; therefore, taking care and being aware are your two best keys to avoiding or managing lymphedema.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: What about using antiperspirant or deodorant under my arm?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: You should not use deodorants or antiperspirants while you are healing from surgery on the armpit on the side of your surgery. Once you are healed, you may use either antiperspirants or deodorants. Some doctors may recommend use of deodorants only. You should talk about this with your healthcare team.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: What can I do about the swelling? Is it permanent?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: You should talk with your doctor about this. Sometimes, elevation of the arm for brief periods throughout the day is adequate to promote fluid drainage. Other methods to reduce swelling include arm exercises and gentle massage that specifically promote lymph drainage. Your doctor should refer you to a practitioner who specializes in lymphedema treatment if you have a persistent problem with this. More severe cases may require use of pressure sleeves to compress the arm. Lymphedema can be a permanent condition in some cases.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: How do I choose a lymphedema therapist?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Lymphedema therapists have a range of training options. The programs they attend vary in length. When you are choosing a therapist, you might want to consider how much training he or she has.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: The programs include: LeDuc (6 days of training), Lerner (14 days), Casley-Smith(14 days), Academy of Lymphatic Studies (ALS; 14 days), Klose-Norton (15 days), Foldi (20 days), and Vodder (20 days; some programs teach Vodder "techniques", but only therapists who

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: have completed the entire program are Vodder credentialed). Recently, the Lymphology Association of North America (LANA) began certifying lymphedema therapists who also passed a comprehensive national exam. If you have questions about the trainings, call the National Lymphedema Network at 800.541.3259 or see

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Some questions to ask the lymphedema treatment center

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Does it provide combined decongestive therapy (CDT)? (This includes skin care, manual lymphatic drainage (MLD), bandaging and exercises.)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: What training/experience do its therapists have in CDT?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Is there a physician with training in lymphedema available for consultation?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Does the center provide patient education in exercises, skin care, self-massage and self-bandaging?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Will the initial therapy be done daily, and for how many days? (Generally, therapy is given at least five days in a row for early stage, and up to four weeks if the lymphedema is more advanced.)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Manual Lymph Drainage is a massage technique used to improve the flow of lymph using light, rhythmic strokes. This therapy may be effective for the lymphedema that sometimes follows breast surgery.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b a font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b a font font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Menopause is the absence of menstrual periods due to reduced function of the ovaries. This can occur naturally with aging, or from damage to the ovaries. This naturally occurs in women beginning in their 40s and 50s.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Will chemotherapy cause me to experience menopause?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Before menopause, your ovaries produce estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for your monthly menstrual cycle and reproduction. Some chemotherapy drugs interrupt (temporarily or permanently) ovarian function, which can result in early (or chemotherapy-induced) menopause. This type of menopause can be permanent and has the same effect on your body as naturally-occurring menopause.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: What are some of the typical side effects of menopause?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Hot flashes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, and irregularity or absence of monthly menstrual periods are the most common effects of menopause. Menopause is also associated with bone loss due to reduced calcium stores in the bone.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: After chemotherapy treatment, some women resume their menstrual cycle. If you do not, you should seek advice about calcium replacement and exercise to promote bone health.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: What can I do to manage side effects of menopause, such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: You should discuss menopause management strategies with your doctor or nurse. For hot flashes, there are medications available; also, many people are beginning to explore the use of alternative therapies, such as soy products or herbs. You should check with your doctor before proceeding with this approach. You must always be cautious about the possibility of drug interactions when taking supplements or herbals in addition to medications.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Other considerations include choosing loose-fitting, comfortable clothing and regulating the temperature control to suit your preference.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Vaginal dryness can be addressed through the use of lubricants prior to sexual activity. There are many products available without prescription to remedy this problem. Persistent vaginal itching should be investigated to rule out the possibility of infection (see also the section below on

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font a strong span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b a font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b a font font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Osteoporosis or "porous bones" is a condition of decreased bone mass. Bone is living tissue that continuously undergoes breakdown and rebuilding (at a cellular level) as a normal body process. Peak bone mass is usually reached by age 38. After that, bone begins to lose mass as part of the aging process. As bone mass is lost, bones become brittle. Men generally lose 20-30% of their bone mass over their lifetime, and women generally lose 45-50% of their bone mass. Decreased bone mass can lead to an increased risk of bone breakage and disability.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Why is this important to me now, and what are the risk factors?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: As a person receiving cancer treatment, you are at increased risk for osteoporosis. Risk factors for osteoporosis include:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Ethnicity—more prevalent in Caucasian (white) and Asian women

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Chemotherapy can interfere with your normal production of hormones due to its effect on ovarian function. Reduction or failure of ovarian function automatically places you at increased risk for osteoporosis. It is important that you discuss prevention and treatment strategies with your doctor or nurse.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Would I know if I had osteoporosis? Can I be tested for it?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Early changes in bone density are usually painless. Most people don’t know they have osteoporosis until they break a bone. That is why it is important to know the risk factors and to learn what you can do to prevent bone deterioration.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Testing can be done for osteoporosis. First, you should have a thorough health history and physical exam to determine your risk factors for osteoporosis. Then, your doctor will discuss or recommend your having a bone mineral density test if you are considered to be at high risk. It is a safe, painless and non-invasive test. This establishes your baseline bone density and provides useful information in determining the best course of action for you.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: In North Carolina, bone mineral density (BMD) tests are available in some pharmacies. The cost of measuring the BMD in the heel is generally around $30, and this correlates well with the trabicular (spine) bone. This test reveals very little about the cortical (hip) bones, so you will not get the whole picture. However, the test will give you a reasonable assessment and baseline information that you can take to your doctor to see if further testing is needed. The test takes about five minutes or less and is pain free. You can have this test done without a referral from your doctor.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Can I help prevent osteoporosis from happening to me?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Yes. There are a number of prevention strategies that are recommended to reduce your risk for osteoporosis:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Including Vitamin D and calcium in your diet

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Avoiding animal protein, salt and caffeine

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Quitting smoking and avoiding excessive alcohol intake

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Taking medications that reduce the natural bone breakdown process

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Increasing your weight-bearing exercise, such as walking or lifting weights.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Again, your healthcare team should advise you in regard to these strategies, but you should not hesitate to initiate this discussion with them.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Every woman’s image of their body and sexuality is unique. No two people have exactly the same response or feelings when they learn they have breast cancer. If a mastectomy is performed, this can be overwhelming and emotionally difficult for some women. For others, it is a relief to have the cancer removed. Treatment for cancer, such as chemotherapy, can cause physical changes that may interfere with a woman's sexuality.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: In addition, breasts are a part of many womens' sexual identity. Breasts are symbolic of nurturing, sustaining new life and intimacy. The loss of a breast can be threatening to body image and sense of self.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: If I have a mastectomy, will I be disfigured?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Mastectomies today are done to preserve muscle, so there is much less disfigurement than there used to be. It is very important that you discuss this topic fully with your surgeons. If you are interested in reconstruction, you may want to consider options regarding breast reconstruction at the time of your initial surgery. If so, you should be referred to a plastic surgeon for a full discussion of your options. In some situations, reconstruction is not advised at the time of your initial surgery, but can be done at a later date after all of your cancer treatment has been completed. Reconstruction can also be chosen years down the road.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: What if I choose not to have reconstruction?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: If you wish to use one, external breast prosthetics (breast forms) are available to help minimize the visual alteration of losing a breast. There are many different options available to you. You might want to consider this, too, when deciding about surgery and potential reconstruction options. (Also see the section on

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Will my sex life be different after breast cancer?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Chemotherapy for breast cancer can sometime cause a woman to go into premature, or early, menopause. This can be difficult for a woman physically, emotionally and sexually. The symptoms of early menopause are sometime more severe than those that occur with natural menopause. These symptoms can include hot flashes, vaginal dryness, and low sexual desire, as well as depression, anxiety and increased irritability. Other menopausal issues include increased risk of heart disease and osteoporosis.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: Are there solutions to the sexual problems I might face?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: The good news is that there are solutions for these problems. Hot flashes can be treated with specific drugs prescribed by a doctor. Some women also have found Vitamin E or soy products to be helpful.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Vaginal dryness can be improved by the liberal use of a lubricant such as Lubrin, K-Y Jelly, Ortho Personal Lubricant, Surgilube, Today Personal Lubricant or Astroglide. Replens, a vaginal moisturizer, can be used three times a week. Recent studies have found that both Estrace, a estrogen cream used vaginally, or Estring, a vaginal ring with slow release of estrogen, restore the vaginal tissues without increasing estrogen in the rest of the body. Ask your doctor about these options.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Persistent, low sexual desire is sometimes treated with androgens. You can have your hormone levels checked and discuss this option with a doctor. Other ways of increasing desire are reading erotic literature or watching erotic videos. Almost all women who were orgasmic before cancer treatment can be so again although sometimes it takes relearning and practice.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: If needed, doctors can also prescribe therapies that address other menopausal issues (depression, anxiety, irritability, increased risk of heart disease and osteoporosis). Several new, improved therapies are now available.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: See the publications and organizations in

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: below for more help with managing menopausal symptoms.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: How will my spouse or lover feel about me after surgery?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: It is very important that you discuss this with your partner. Open, honest communication about your feelings and theirs is very beneficial to your overall sense of well being and the intimacy you experience before and after treatment. Your healthcare team may include a social worker or psychologist who can specifically help you to address your feelings and fears regarding sexuality and intimacy. Your acceptance of your body changes will affect how others react to you. It is important for you to be open about your feelings to yourself and to your spouse, lover or partner.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Always remember that who you are has nothing to do with your breasts (although perhaps they may have played a part in your self-esteem or sexual identity prior to your surgery). You are special no matter what the size of shape of your body, and you deserve to be in an open, honest and loving relationship with someone who cares about you--and accepts you--because of who you are in your heart, mind and soul.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
content: I'm single and not in a relationship. How and when do I tell someone new in my life about my breast cancer and surgery?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: This is not a question with any easy answers, but there are some things you can consider when you find yourself in a new relationship:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: First, have you reached your own personal level of acceptance of your body and your experience with breast cancer?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Have you accepted the possible changes to your body which might later be issues in a relationship, such as early menopause and inability to bear children, or possibility of recurrence?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Are you comfortable enough with yourself and your experience to share it with someone else?

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Decide whether this new person is one who would be caring and sensitive to your needs. Are you comfortable enough to open yourself up and share it with this person? If not, then perhaps either the timing is not right or the person is not the one for you.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Only you can decide whether you are ready to enter into a new relationship with someone. And you alone are the only person who can know whether you feel comfortable and "safe enough" in a new relationship to share your feelings, your experience and your body.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Publishes "Sexuality and Cancer", an excellent, free resource to address the sexual needs of women with a cancer diagnosis or in premature menopause. Call to order or see the web site. ACS provides information and services for all forms of cancer; diagnosis, treatment, and many other topics. Programs offered by ACS include: CanSurmount, I Can Cope (coping support), Reach to Recovery (rehabilitation after surgery and support), and Resources Information and Guidance. Free educational materials available on a wide variety of topics relating to cancer.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Provides support and assistance on issues concerning menopause. The AMF has support groups across the country. Call or write to order articles on menopause-related issues such as anxiety, coping, sexuality, hormone replacement therapy, phytoestrogens, bone health, premature ovarian failure, etc.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Has information on breast cancer and treatments. Web site has good resource links to books, organizations, and breast cancer awareness events.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: All services free. Provides emotional support, information, and practical help. Staffed by trained oncology social workers. One to one counseling, support groups, information, educational programs, and referrals for services available. Publishes A Helping Hand, a free resource guide for people with cancer. Call (800) 813-HOPE or order through Web site. Web site has comprehensive resource information.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Publishes "Menopause: What Every Woman Should Know", an excellent, free resource about menopause helpful for women who have had breast cancer. Call 1-800-HORMONE to order or see the web site to download free.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Provides information about breast cancer, menopause, and other women’s health issues.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Addresses post-treatment needs of women with breast cancer through educational programs, newsletter, call in help-line for survivors and family members. Toll-free survivor's helpline 888-753-LBBC available Tuesdays 11am-3pm. Many conference tapes, workshop tapes, and videotapes about survivor issues also available.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: National Alliance of Breast Cancer Organizations (NABCO)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: This network of organizations is an information and education resource on breast cancer. Publishes a yearly, comprehensive Breast Cancer Resources booklet which includes many aspects of breast cancer diagnosis, treatment and issues. Call to order one, or view the resource list online at their excellent Web site.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Education and guidance for lymphedema patients, healthcare professionals, and the general public. Referrals to treatment centers, health care professionals and support groups. Resource materials, a toll-free recorded information line, pen pals/net pals peer support, lymphedema alert bracelets, and newsletter also available. Extensive guide on how to avoid lymphedema.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Offers education, information, support and advocacy. Publishes several informational booklets (including a Spanish language one) and an osteoporosis exercise video. Has an electronic support group called "Linking Up" which offers peer support for men and women ages 20-50; call or email supgroup@nof.org to sign up. Web site has much information and an online "Find a Doctor" service; bone health newsletters offered by email.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: A national, nonprofit advocacy and public interest organization devoted solely to women's health issues. Call the clearinghouse Tues. and Thurs. 9-5:30 to request information on a range of topics, including breast alternative therapies for menopause; osteoporosis; tamoxifen, and others. Can also see Web site for fact sheets on different topics.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Offers comprehensive information on women's health topics.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Promotes understanding of menopause. Has much information and publications about menopause and menopause-related issues. Has lists of menopause clinicians, discussions groups, and a reading list. Much of their information is available for download on their Web site.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Osteoporosis and Related Bone Diseases-- National Resource Center (ORBD-NRC)

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Clearinghouse for information about osteoporosis, Paget's disease and related disorders. Includes a sign-up for an osteoporosis listserv (online discussion group).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Provides information about osteoporosis programs in North Carolina.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Provides support and information about infertility. Has information about infertility, how to select an infertility specialist, and other topics. Offers a Helpline to order publications, give information and direct you to resources in your area.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Provides information and suggestions about how to manage problems related to sexuality after breast cancer.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: After Cancer: A Guide to Your New Life

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: , by Wendy Schlessel Harpham, MD (HarperCollins, Inc., 1995). A warm, informative overview written by a physician and cancer survivor. She discusses sexuality in the chapter "Where did my Libido Go?" and offers practical advice.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Coping With Lymphedema: A Practical Guide to Understanding, Treating and Living with Lymphedema

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: , by Joan Swirsky, RN, and Diane Sacket Nannery (Avery Publishing Group, 1998). A practical guide to understanding, treating and living with lymphedema caused by treatment for breast cancer. Can be ordered by calling 800-548-5757, Ext. 123.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Dr. Susan Love’s Hormone Book: Making Informed Choices About Menopause

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: by Susan M. Love, MD, with Karen Lindsey (Random House, 1997). Offers comprehensive information on menopause and coping with symptoms, and addresses concerns about breast cancer. Also includes a listing of resources.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Living in the Post-Mastectomy Body: Learning to Live in and Love Your Body Again

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: by Becky Zuckweiler, MS, RN, CS (Hartley & Marks, 1998). As a nurse, psychotherapist and breast cancer survivor (who had a double mastectomy), Zuckweiler guides women through all aspects of recovery, focusing on regaining confidence in your body and developing a comfortable self-image and intimate relationships.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: , by Jeanne Petrek, MD, Peter I. Pressman, MD, Robert A. Smith, PhD (1998). Results from a workshop on breast cancer treatment-related lymphedema and lymphedema resource guide. A bit technical and scientific; useful for health professionals. Order online at American Cancer Society’s web site at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Lymphedema: A Breast Cancer Patient’s Guide to Prevention and Healing

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: , by Jeannie Burt and Gwen White, PT (Hunter House, 2000). Provides clear information on what lymphedema is and why it occurs. Describes treatment procedures to suit a range of needs and emphasizes that lymphedema can be treated successfully. Covers preventing lymphedema, reducing lymphedema through professional therapy and self-massage and more.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: (magazine) Includes helpful information on dealing and living with symptoms of menopause and other interesting articles regarding women’s health. Published biannually (

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: in OB-GYN offices) by American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. Contact 202-484-3321. See also

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Sexuality and Cancer: For the Woman Who Has Cancer and Her Partner

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: (# 4657), by American Cancer Society. (FREE) A brochure available from the ACS. Call 800-ACS-2345 or see their web site at

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: by Leslie R. Schover, Ph.D. (John Wiley and Sons, 1997). Addresses how treatment may interfere emotionally and physically with male and female sexual function and fertility. Offers help for survivors and their partners learn to enjoy sex again and make informed choices about having children. (Schover also wrote the influential 1988 book,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Sexuality and Cancer: For the Woman Who Has Cancer and Her Partner

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Strong Women, Strong Bones: Everything You Need to Know to Prevent, Treat and Beat Osteoporosis

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: , by Miriam Nelson, Ph.D., with Sara Wernick, PhD. (Putnam Publishing Group, 2000). This book teaches women how to recognize, prevent and treat osteoporosis through exercise (strength training, weight-bearing aerobic exercise, stretching and balance) and nutrition. Tufts University nutrition researcher, Miriam Nelson, and award-winning health writer, Sarah Wernick team up on their third "Strong Women" book to bring you the latest science about osteoporosis.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: What Every Woman Facing Breast Cancer Should Know About Lymphedema: Hand and Arm Care Following Surgery or Radiation Therapy for Breast Cancer

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: , by American Cancer Society (ACS). (FREE) A brochure available from the American Cancer Society. Call 800-ACS-2345 or see

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Without Estrogen: Natural Remedies for Menopause and Beyond

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: by Dee Ito & Barbara Herbert (Crown Publishing, 1995). Offers options for managing the symptoms of menopause for women who cannot or choose not to rely on hormone replacement therapy.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p b font a span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Bosom Buddies: Breast Cancer and Lymphedema Support Group

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Web site has info about lymphedema, case histories, compression pumps and more.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: A non-profit organization to promote education, awareness, research, assistance, and support to lymphedema patients and their doctors. Website has info about lymphedema, including travel, psychological aspects, insurance and other issues. Also "Ask A Therapist" online.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Information about lymphedema, finding support groups, finding/choosing a therapist, lymphedema alert bracelets, news, a resource guide, and educational materials.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Breast Cancer and Sexuality: Surviving and Thriving

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Information on the ways breast cancer can affect sexuality and how to cope with difficulties in sexuality and intimacy.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Has info about menopause secondary to breast cancer, how to help with hot flashes, and a resource list.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Oncolink’s Page About Cancer and Sexuality

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Has several resources and information about about sexuality and cancer, including a link to sexuality after breast cancer.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong span
content: Power Surge: A warm and caring community for women in menopause

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Information and frequently-asked questions about menopause, interactive chats, medical consultants, message board, Ask the Experts, resources, bookstore and more.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Questions and Answers About Hormone Replacement Therapy,

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Questions and answers about menopause, HRT, types of HRT, risks and benefits, alternatives, etc.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Sexuality from the American Cancer Society

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: The site has a comprehensive sexuality section for women who have cancer and their partners. Click to the left on "Living With Cancer," then choose "Coping with Cancer." Choose Sexuality & Cancer from the list of topics.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
content: Sexuality from the National Cancer Institute

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: Discusses sexual problems after cancer (psychological and physical factors) and treatment.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font strong span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: (note: ACOR.org, the source of most of these groups, is called the Association for Online Resources. They have over 100 public online support groups which provide information and community to patients, caregivers, or anyone looking for answers about cancer or related conditions).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: On the web site, click on Mailing Lists to the left, then page down to "CANCER-FERTILITY" to sign up. This group is for people concerned with fertility issues after cancer.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: On the web site, click on Mailing Lists to the left, and page down to "CANCER-SEXUALITY" to sign up. The group is concerned with sexuality after a cancer diagnosis.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td font p font b span
html body text table tbody tr td font p font span
content: On the web site, click on Mailing Lists, then page down to "LYMPHEDEMA" to sign up. The group is for people concerned with lymphedema.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td p font font strong span
html body text table tbody tr td p font font span
content: On the web site, click on Mailing Lists on the left, then page down to "OSTEO-P" to sign up. This group is concerned with osteoporosis.
